questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the dose-response curves for benzodiazepines and barbiturates is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Benzodiazepines demonstrate a steeper dose-response curve compared to barbiturates.

options.label: B
options.text: Benzodiazepines have a wider therapeutic index compared to barbiturates.

options.label: C
options.text: Both benzodiazepines and barbiturates display a linear dose-response relationship.

options.label: D
options.text: Benzodiazepines and barbiturates show similar potency but differ in their maximal efficacy on the dose-response curve.

questions.correct_answer: B. Benzodiazepines have a wider therapeutic index compared to barbiturates.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding GABA receptors is incorrect? GABA-A receptors are dimeric metabotropic receptors and mediate inhibitory neurotransmission. GABA-B receptors are inhibitory G protein-coupled receptors and mediate slow inhibitory neurotransmission through the efflux of potassium. Activation of GABA-A receptors results in the efflux of chloride ions into the neuron. α and γ subunits of GABA-A receptors modulate drug efficacy. GABA-C receptors are structurally and functionally similar to GABA-A receptors
questions.explanation:
Types

MOA

Drugs

GABA A
  • Pentameric ionotropic ligand-gated Cl– channels
  • 5 Subunits: 2 α, 2 beta and 1 γ
  • α and γ subunits affect the efficacy of benzodiazepine binding and channel modulation
  • Fast inhibitory neurotransmission through hyperpolarisation of the neurons by Cl- ion influx

1. Benzodiazepines (diazepam etc.)

  • Acts as a positive allosteric modulator
  • Increase the frequency of opening of the GABA-A receptor.

2. Barbiturates

  • Binds at multiple sites
  • Increase mean open time with no effect on frequency.

3. Volatile anaesthetics

4. Brexanolone (neuroactive steroid)

5. Ethanol

GABA B
  • Metabotropic inhibitory G protein-coupled receptor
  • Heterodimers with 2 subunits
  • Gi type of GPCR
  • Inhibit adenylyl cyclase, activate K+ channels (K+ efflux), and reduce Ca2+ conductance
  • Slow inhibitory neurotransmission

1. Baclofen (muscle relaxant)

2. gamma-hydroxybutyric acid ( narcolepsy)

GABA C
  • Ionotropic receptor
  • Structurally and functionally similar to GABA A receptors.
  • Location: Retina

questions.text: Arrange the following barbiturates based on their duration of action from shortest to longest: Secobarbital Phenobarbital Thiopental Pentobarbital
questions.explanation:
Type

Duration

Drugs

Ultra short-acting

5-15 mins

Redistribution into fats

    • Uses: general anesthesia, narcoanalysis
    • Side effect: Acute intermittent porphyria, thrombosis with arterial injection
  2. Methohexitone:
    • Use: DOC in Electroconvulsive therapy
  3. Propofol
  4. Etomidate
  5. Ketamine
  6. Fentanyl (Opioid)

Short-acting

3-8 hours

Drugs ending with -barbitone or -barbital

  1. Butobarbitone
  2. Amobarbitone
  3. Secobarbital
  4. Pentobarbitone

Long-acting

Days
  1. Phenobarbitone (Phenobarbital)
  2. Primidone: Used in essential tremors

questions.text: A 42-year-old male with treatment-resistant major depressive disorder is scheduled for electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). The anesthesiologist plans to use a rapid-onset medication to minimize the side effects and facilitate quick recovery. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?

A 2-day-old neonate is brought to the hospital with abnormal jerking movements in arms and legs. On examination, electroencephalogram (EEG) recording revealed abnormal electrical activity in the brain. What is the drug of choice for managing this patient condition?
questions.explanation:
Phenobarbital (Phenobarbitone)

Uses
  • DOC in Neonatal seizures
  • DOC in Neonatal jaundice: Crigler Najjar syndrome type 2
  • DOC in Gilbert syndrome

MOA

Increase GABA-A receptor Cl- channel opening duration without affecting the frequency.

Pharmacokinetics
  • CYP3A4 Inducer (induces UDP-GT activity in Gilbert syndrome)
  • pH-dependent renal excretion

Side effects
  • Paradoxical excitation: Seen in children
  • Hyperkinesia
  • Excessive sensation and pain perception
  • Rapid metabolisation of oral contraceptives

Contraindication

Acute intermittent porphyria (CYP enzyme inducers increase heme demand)

questions.text: A 25-year-old student with a past history of suicide is brought to the emergency by his roommate, who found him unresponsive with an empty bottle of unknown pills. On examination, the patient is comatose with shallow breathing, hypotension, and decreased reflexes with mild pupillary dilatation. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features

Management

CNS depression, coma

Airway protection

Hypotension

IV fluids, vasopressors if needed

QRS widening, arrhythmias (on ECG)

IV sodium bicarbonate

Seizures

Benzodiazepines

questions.text: Duration of action of which of the following benzodiazepines is determined by its rate of biotransformation?
questions.explanation:
CLASS A

CLASS B

Drugs in this class need to be converted into their active metabolites

Drugs in this class are in their active forms

Active metabolites are biotransformed slower than parent drugs - duration of action of drugs has little to no relationship with rate of biotransformation of parent drugs

Duration of action is determined by the rate of biotransformation of the drug itself

All benzodiazepines except those in class B
  • Lorazepam
  • Oxazepam
  • Temazepam
  • Triazolam
  • Midazolam

questions.text: Which of the following drugs selectively helps improve insomnia without muscle relaxation?

A 45-year-old blind patient presents with difficulty falling asleep and maintaining sleep. The patient reports a history of insomnia that has persisted despite trying various lifestyle modifications. Which of the following drugs is approved for the treatment of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Details

Non-24-hour Sleep-Wake Disorder

This disorder occurs predominantly in blind individuals due to the lack of light perception, which helps to regulate the body’s natural circadian rhythm. Without light cues, the individual’s sleep-wake cycle becomes unaligned with the 24-hour day, leading to irregular sleep patterns.

Symptoms

Common symptoms include difficulty falling asleep, maintaining sleep, and daytime sleepiness. The symptoms worsen as the person’s sleep-wake cycle shifts, typically becoming progressively worse each day.

Treatment with Tasimelteon

Tasimelteon works by mimicking the action of melatonin at its receptors, specifically the MT1 and MT2 receptors, which help regulate the sleep-wake cycle. It is FDA-approved for blind patients with Non-24-hour sleep-wake disorder to improve sleep onset and maintenance.

Administration and Effectiveness

Tasimelteon is usually administered at bedtime and has shown effectiveness in improving both sleep onset and sleep duration in patients with Non-24. It aligns the individual’s circadian rhythm with the 24-hour day cycle.

Drug

Mechanism

Uses

Half-life

Metabolism

Ramelteon

MT1 & MT2 receptor agonist

Insomnia (night shift workers, jet lag)

2 hours

Metabolized by CYP1A, CYP2C, and CYP3A4; high first-pass metabolism

Tasimelteon

MT1 & MT2 receptor agonist

Non-24-hour sleep-wake disorder (blind individuals), Smith-Magenis syndrome (night-time disturbances)

2 hours

Metabolized by CYP1A2 and CYP3A4

questions.text: A patient with sleep disturbances is prescribed suvorexant. How does this drug help in improving insomnia?

A 35-year-old male presents with severe headache, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, disorientation, and fruity breath odour after consuming homemade liquor 12 hours ago. Blood gas analysis shows pH 7.25, bicarbonate 12 mmol/L, and anion gap metabolic acidosis. What is the drug of choice for his condition?
questions.explanation:
• Adulteration in Country liquor.
  • Solvent in industrial processes.
  • Antifreeze.

Mechanism of Action
  • Methanol ⟶ Formaldehyde (oxidation by alcohol dehydrogenase).
  • Formaldehyde ⟶ Formic acid (oxidation by aldehyde dehydrogenase).
  • Formic Acid ⟶ Inhibition of Cytochrome c Oxidase ⟶ Cellular Hypoxia and Metabolic Acidosis.

Features of Toxicity
  • CNS: Headache, dizziness, confusion, ataxia, seizures
  • Ocular: Blurred ("snowfield" vision).
  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, fruity breath and abdominal pain
  • Metabolic: Severe metabolic acidosis, elevated anion gap

Treatment

Mnemonic: SHAFE

  • Sodium Bicarbonate to correct metabolic acidosis
  • Hemodialysis to remove methanol and its metabolites
  • Antidote: Fomepizole or Ethanol to inhibit ADH
  • Folinic acid or folic acid to enhance formate metabolism.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol abuse is admitted to the hospital due to severe alcohol withdrawal symptoms. After stabilisation, he expresses his desire to overcome his alcohol dependence and seeks assistance from the healthcare team. Which of the following is not an anti-craving drug commonly used in the management of alcohol dependence?
questions.explanation:
Drug Name

Mechanism of Action

Notes

FDA-
approved anti-craving drugs

Naltrexone (Option A)

Blocks opioid receptors

Reduces cravings and desire to drink

Acamprosate (Option B)

Modulates glutamate & GABA systems

Reduces cravings and helps maintain abstinence

Not FDA-
approved (off-label use)

Baclofen

GABA agonist

Helps with alcohol withdrawal symptoms

Gabapentin

& Topiramate (Option D)

Modulates GABA & glutamate systems

Helps with alcohol withdrawal symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the mechanism of action of disulfiram is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Disulfiram inhibits the enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to an accumulation of acetaldehyde in the body.

options.label: B
options.text: Acetaldehyde accumulation results in unpleasant symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and headache when alcohol is consumed.

options.label: C
options.text: Disulfiram increases the production of dopamine in the brain, reducing the desire to consume alcohol.

options.label: D
options.text: Disulfiram therapy is often used as an adjunct in the treatment of alcohol dependence.

questions.correct_answer: C. Disulfiram increases the production of dopamine in the brain, reducing the desire to consume alcohol.

questions.text: A patient recovering from alcohol dependence on disulfiram developed a fungal infection and was given an antifungal medication. Shortly after, the patient developed symptoms reminiscent of a disulfiram-like reaction. Which of the following antifungal drugs is most likely to have caused this reaction?
